description: Authentication success for user susan.gregory using dovecot; repeated success logs suggest potential account compromise or credential misuse.
Duplicate successful login alert for susan.gregory from the same source; likely part of same session.
Authentication success for user damian.jordan; rising login count indicates possible misuse of valid credentials.
Repeat alert for damian.jordan login; likely same session and duplicate log entry.
Same successful login by damian.jordan appearing again in logs; another duplicate entry.
Another login success for user susan.gregory; consistent with suspicious behavior due to high firedtimes count.
Repeated login event for susan.gregory; same timestamp and session details.
Triplicate login entry for susan.gregory; no sign of variation suggesting additional activity.
First login success seen for michael.davis; high firedtimes suggests this is part of a broader suspicious activity pattern.
Second success log for michael.davis with identical context; most likely a system-level duplicate entry.
Successful IMAP login via PLAIN method for user damian.jordan. Could signal credential misuse or normal mail access.
IMAP login success for john.hammond from consistent IP—likely legitimate mail client use.
Second IMAP login for john.hammond shortly after first—consistent with client re-authentication.
Suricata flagged TLS invalid record/traffic from fast.wistia.com—suggests malformed or crafted TLS traffic.
Suricata detected invalid TLS handshake from external state.gov—possible scanning or malformed traffic.
Suricata alert on internal host initiating invalid TLS handshake to state.gov—likely outbound suspicion.
Another record of Suricata invalid TLS record/traffic on same session—confirms protocol anomaly.
Snort logged TLS invalid handshake message mirroring Suricata alert—verifies detection.
Suricata flagged invalid TLS record from in.hotjar.com—again showing malformed TLS traffic inbound.
Snort listed again TLS invalid handshake to hotjar.com—duplicates signal consistent protocol anomaly detection.
SURICATA TLS invalid record/traffic and handshake message indicates malformed TLS communications potentially used to bypass inspection or probe services.
TLS handshake message is malformed, repeated multiple times from same JA3 fingerprint, could indicate use of obfuscation or evasion tools.
Identical repeated invalid TLS record alerts suggest active reconnaissance or malformed client attempts to evade detection.
Invalid TLS handshake from external IP suggests either misconfiguration or potentially malicious scanning/probing.
Legitimate authentication to Dovecot IMAP using known account; could be lateral movement or persistence.
Repeated Dovecot IMAP successful logins from same source could indicate use of compromised credentials.
Ongoing logins by same user at various times may indicate persistent access by an attacker.
SSH daemon received connection without identification string, common in scanning or brute-force pre-checks.
Inbound SSH with missing identification string on firewall; behavior consistent with probing.
SSH connection lacking proper protocol handshake often occurs during automated scans or fingerprinting.
SSH connection attempt without proper identification string suggests a potential scan or reconnaissance attempt over SSH.
HTTP 403 error from GET request to root path indicates possible probing or misconfigured access, though limited info.
Invalid SMTP reply detected by Suricata, indicating protocol misuse or potential tunneling attempt.
Client denied access to web root by server config; could indicate probing for misconfigured or exposed directories.
GET request with Nmap scripting engine in user-agent string targeting a known detection path shows automated scanning.
POST request to /sdk path using Nmap scripting engine strongly suggests web app enumeration.
Access denied to web root; similar repeated pattern as part of reconnaissance or vulnerability detection.
Attempted access to a file typically created by Nmap scan scripts; clearly part of automated scan.
HEAD request with WPScan user-agent probing for plugin paths suggests CMS enumeration attempt.
Multiple 404 responses from HEAD requests to plugin paths using WPScan; typical plugin reconnaissance.
HEAD request for /click-to-chat-for-whatsapp/ with WPScan user-agent; indicative of plugin enumeration.
Probe for /cloudflare/ directory using WPScan; part of systematic plugin discovery.
Use of HEAD against /cloudflare-flexible-ssl/ pattern; automated plugin scan identified.
Batch of HEAD requests for multiple plugins (complianz, companion-auto-update, comet-cache, etc.); systematic enumeration by WPScan.
HEAD request targeting /constant-contact-forms/ with high frequency noted; indicates automated scanning.
HEAD request for /bing-webmaster-tools/ plugin; further evidence of plugin discovery scan.
Scan for /better-wp-security/ plugin directory via WPScan; consistent enumeration behavior.
HEAD request for /easy-login-woocommerce/ plugin; part of continued automated enumeration.
HEAD request for /redis-cache/ plugin; systematic head probes indicate automated plugin scanning.
HEAD request for /amp/ plugin directory; consistent enumeration across many common WP plugins.
HEAD request to known WP plugin path with WPScan user-agent – scanning for vulnerabilities
HEAD request probing attachment endpoint using WPScan user-agent
HEAD access to wp-config.php with WPScan – probing for sensitive config file
HEAD request to another attachment ID via WPScan – continued enumeration
Dovecot authentication success for user – could be legitimate login activity
GET to /academics – non-standard path scan likely probing for hidden pages
GET /access-log.1 – probing for server log files
GET /accountants – sequential path scan for common endpoints
GET /advancedsearch – scanning for advanced search functionality
GET /advert – probing for advertisement endpoint/page
Multiple 404 errors for similar paths suggest automated probing of web directories
Request to /beheer, likely part of localized admin scanning attempts
Access attempt to /wp-admin/user/webcalendar, probing for WordPress plugins or sensitive paths
Access to /wp-admin/user/webcart suggests probing for e-commerce functionality in WordPress
Attempt to access restricted file (.htpasswd_) in plugin directory; potentially trying to enumerate or exploit misconfigured access controls
Request to deprecated or uncommon FrontPage extension endpoint (author.dll) on WordPress; indicates probing for legacy vulnerability
Attempt to access partial/incomplete WordPress paths; likely automated guessing of valid resource paths
Multiple 404s in rapid succession for paths under /wp-includes/js/tinymce/skins/wordpress; dictionary attack against known file names
Targeting WordPress JavaScript resource paths for plugin enumeration or fingerprinting
Access attempts to numerous similar files in WordPress paths indicate automated reconnaissance
Successful authentication using a valid user account (megan.johnson) via Dovecot IMAP service with repeated logins from the same IP, suggesting automated or repeated account usage.
Same login as previous, duplicated across multiple logs (possibly due to log forwarding or central aggregation). Indicates a valid but possibly scripted login behavior.
Another duplicate of the same login attempt by megan.johnson from identical IP and session ID, suggesting log duplication rather than repeated behavior.
New login session by same user (megan.johnson), new timestamp and session ID. Indicates continued use of valid credentials, possibly legitimate or compromised.
Repeated log of the same new login (megan.johnson) from same session, indicating a log mirror rather than a distinct event.
Third record of same login (session ID and timestamp match), suggesting central logging of one event.
Different user (damian.jordan) logging in successfully to another mail server (taylorcruz-mail). Consistent with legitimate usage, but also fits lateral movement via valid credentials.
Suricata flagged HTTP protocol inconsistency - response without matching request, which may indicate malformed traffic, probing, or evasion attempts.
Snort/Suricata duplication of previous anomaly showing TCP traffic anomaly — typical of fuzzing or malformed requests to identify parsing vulnerabilities.
Authentication success from user john.hammond with valid credentials on whittaker-mail. Repeated behavior pattern seen across multiple users may suggest compromised accounts or normal use.
Suricata detected a TLS handshake message that does not conform to expected protocol behavior, indicating potential malformed or malicious TLS traffic.
TLS traffic had an invalid record or structure, pointing to possible protocol manipulation or malformed packet inspection evasion.
Successful authentication using IMAP protocol via dovecot suggests possible use of valid credentials. May be benign or initial access via stolen credentials.
PAM login failure indicates potential password guessing or brute force attempt for user christopher.friedman.
Malformed TLS handshake detected from external IP insight.adsrvr.org, indicating suspicious or tampered SSL session initiation.
Suricata detected outbound TLS connection with invalid handshake to 3.219.152.16, possibly indicative of anomalous or malicious encrypted traffic.
Inbound traffic from 94.245.192.25 flagged for malformed TLS records—suggests evasion attempt or poorly implemented TLS library.
TLS traffic from internal host to feed.theplatform.com shows invalid records, indicating possible misuse or data exfiltration over encrypted channel.
Internal host attempted TLS connection to 199.27.170.188 with a malformed handshake, raising suspicion of potential command and control or obfuscated traffic.
Malformed TLS records from internal to external destination suggest anomaly, possibly due to evasion techniques or encrypted data exfiltration.
User www-data successfully changed UID to phopkins via su command, indicating potential account impersonation or privilege escalation.
PAM session opened for user phopkins by UID 33, confirming successful login session initiation after UID change.
Systemd opened a PAM login session for user phopkins by root (UID 0), indicating elevated privileges granted or maintained.
User phopkins executed sudo command as root with command 'list', showing privilege escalation using sudo.
PAM login session opened for root user by UID 0 after sudo execution, confirming elevated root session.
PAM login session closed for root user, indicating end of sudo session.
User phopkins executed sudo to run recursive ls on /root, accessing sensitive root directory contents.
User phopkins executed sudo command to read /etc/shadow, attempting to access password hashes of all system users.
PAM session opened for root user by UID 0 following sudo command, confirming active root session after privilege escalation.
PAM login session closed for root user, indicating end of elevated session.
